note.p: Birth: Langford Grove, Maldon, Essex, England (12 November 1842)
Death: Terling Place, Witham, Essex (30 June 1919)
Research Field: Physics

Education: Eton; at home; private school at Wimbledon; Harrow School (1857); private school with the Reverend George Townsend Waner who took pupils privately in Torquay (1857); Trinity College, Cambridge (1861). BA (1865, Senior Wrangler and 1st Smith's Prizeman)

Career: Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge (1866-1871); managed his estate of Terling Place, before succeeding to the barony (1873) and passing the job to his brother (1876); Cavendish Professor of Physics, Cambridge succeeding James Clerk Maxwell (1879-1884); Professor of Natural Philosophy, Royal Institution, London (1887-1905); had a private laboratory at Terling Place, where his work on producing diffraction gratings by photgrpahic reduction of hand drawn rulings led to the production of the earliest known so-called Fresnel zone plates - an entry in his notebook in 1871 predates by four years a paper by Soret, previously thought to be the first report of this two dimensional lens, later to find application in Polaroid cameras and used for focusing synchroton radiation. Privy Councillor (1905); discovered argon
President of a Government Committee on Explosives; Scientific Advisor to Trinity House; Lord Lieutenant of Essex (1892-1901); Chancellor of Cambridge University
Honours: OM (1902)
Membership: Fellow
Election Date: 12/06/1873
Medals/Prizes: Rumford Medal 1914; Royal Medal 1882; Copley Medal 1899; Nobel Prize (Physics) 1904 for discovery of argon
Lectures: Bakerian 1902
